coredata.dc:title: Solvents effects on the fluorescence quenching of anthracene by iodide ions
coredata.dc:creator: Mac, Marek
Wach, Anna
Najbar, Jan
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
Fluorescence quenching of anthracene by iodide ions in ethanol and propanol solutions in the temperature range 293–333 K was investigated under stationary conditions. The fluorescence quenching can be satisfactorily described using Marcus-type theory. Analysis of the experimental data indicates the importance of solvent-dielectric-relaxation properties for the fluorescence quenching.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 176, number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS II January 1991 Solvent effects on the fluorescence quenching of anthracene by iodide ions Marek Mac, Anna Wach and Jan Najbar Faculty qf Chemistry, Jagiellonian University, 3 Karasia, 30-OoOKrakew, Poland Received 7 June 1990; in final form 25 October 1990 Fluorescence quenching of anthracene by iodide ions in ethanol and propanol solutions in the temperature range 293 333 K was investigated under stationary conditions. The fluorescence quenching can be satisfactorily described using Marcus-type the- ory. Analysis of the experimental data indicates the importance of solvent-dielectric-relaxation properties for the fluorescence quenching. 1. Introduction Solvent motions and relaxation processes play an important role in the dynamics of chemical reactions Il 14]. Electron-transfer reactions have been ob- jects of numerous studies [l 25]. Much attention has been given to the problem of adiabaticity of the electron transfer; a number of analytical expressions for the rate constant have been presented in the lit- erature [l 7]. Experimentally, the compounds con- taining an electron donor in close proximity to the electron-acceptor subunits are well suited for a study of the solvent-dielectric-relaxation effect on the rates of the electron transfer [16 21]. Similar conditions should also be important for bimolecular electron- transfer reactions in solution. Reaction rates in so- lution are affected by the diffusion velocity of reac- tants [14,26 29]. For this reason, experimental evi- dence concerning the influence of solvent relaxational properties on the electron-transfer rates in bimolec- ular reactions has been difficult to demonstrate. In this paper, we have developed a method to separate the effects of diffusion and solvent relaxation, thus making it possible to study the dynamical influence of the solvent on bimolecular electron transfer. Recently, we have analyzed the fluorescence- quenching-rate coefficient of aromatic hydrocarbons by iodide and bromide ions in methanol ethanol mixtures. Specifically, its dependence on the free en- thalpy of electron transfer was studied [141. For negative values of AG, the quenching is due to elec- tron transfer. Temperature dependences of the quenching-rate coefficients indicate the importance of solvent-dielectric relaxation in quenching reac- tion rates. For AG>O, the quenching occurs due to a temperature-independent process (external heavy- atom effect). En this paper, we present more direct evidence of the influence o~ solvent relaxation properties on the electron-transfer probability. The experimental sys- tem was chosen so that electron transfer is the major quenching process, and the diffusion limitation to the quenching process is not too large. The quench- ing-rate coefficient is reduced approximately by half relative to that predicted without diffusion control. 2. Electron-transfer rates We consider the case of a slow diffusion where the distances travelled by acceptor molecules during the Landau Zener time are small [3,5,6]. Under these conditions, we can assume that the electron-transfer rates are dependent on donor acceptor separations only. The time dependence of the rate constants re- sults from the time dependence of the distance be- tween donor and acceptor. The quenching-rate con~ stant, which is derived from the Stern Volmer 167 0009-2614/91/S 03.50 1991 Elsevier Science Publishers By. (North-HoUand) CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS Il January 1991 Volume 176, number 2 analysis of the luminescence quenching, is related to the Laplace transform of the time-dependent bi- molecular rate coefficient. The explicit formula is [26 29] I V(r, m) 2= j V(r) I2exp( S) Stm/rn! with S=AIN/hQ. In eq. (4), AG is the free enthalpy change between products and reactants, while 1(r) is the solvent re organization energy [15]. 21N is the internal reor ganization energy and V( r) is the matrix element of (1) the electronic coupling. The longitudinal dielectric relaxation time, TL, can be evaluated from the Froehlich formula TL = (e=/ e5) TD with c, and e~ being the optical and the static dielectric constant of the solvent, respectively, while TD is the Debye relaxa- tion time [3,4,13,14,20]. When the internal reorganization energy, 21N, ~S very small (S= 0), eq. (4) simplifies to the equation derived by Rips and Jortner [3]. Eq. (4) predicts the dependence of the electron- transfer rate on the longitudinal relaxation time, tL. On the other hand, for tL ~O, eq. (4) reduces to the (2) well-known Jortner formula valid in the nonadi- abatic limit [30,31]. The solvent reorganization energy 2(r) is approx- imatedby [15] kq = 4~N p J S(r) ~(r, p) r2 dr forp=1/t, where a is the contact separation, N is Avogadro s number divided by l0~, S(r) is the reaction rate for donor and acceptor separated by the distance r, and ~(r,p) is the Laplace transform ofp(r, t), the time- dependent pair-distribution function for donor and acceptor molecules. The function ~ p) is the so- lution to the equation [27,28] (d2 2d\ D r rdrj Ip+S(r)]IJ(r,p)= l, where D is the diffusion coefficient (D=D~ +D0). We use the simplest boundary conditions appropri- ate for long-range tunnelling, the reflecting boundary conditions, dfl(r,p) ~ d dp(r,p) ~ dr r=a an dr r~ In recent years, much attention has been given to the problem of the adiabaticity of the electron trans- fer in different media [l 71. In a number of papers, formulae were derived that interpolate between the nonadiabatic and adiabatic limits [l 7]. Experi- mental evidence for adiabatic and nonadiabatic elec- tron-transfer regimes refers mainly to monomolec- ular electron-transfer reactions [13,16 21]. Here, we limit our attention to one particular formula which allows us to discuss the dependencies of the quench- ing-rate coefficient on the solvent-dielectric-relaxa- tion properties [3,4]. For the electron-transfer probability, we use the formula proposed by Onuchic [4], S( ) (2it/~)I J/(r, m)I2[41E.Z(r)kT]~ 2 r _~ l+(4~/~)IV(r,m)J2rL/A(v) xexp{ [AG+mhQ+A(r)]2/42(r)kT}, where A(r)=Ne2/4ite0(1/2a1 +l/2a2 l/r) (5) (3) where a1 and a2 are the effective radii of the reac- tants, e is the electron charge, and c, = n2 where n is the refractive index of the solvent. For the elec- tronic coupling matrix element, we use the standard formula [16 21], V(r)=V(a)exp[ a(r a)/2] (6) where V( a) and a are parameters. The calculations of the quenching-rate coefficients were performed using the numerical method of solving eqs. (2) and (3) and numerical integration of eq. (1) [26,28,32]. 3. Experimental Anthracene was purified by crystallization from ethanol. Potassium iodide and sodium iodide were Analar Grade. Ethanol and propanol were dried over anhydrous sodium carbonate and column distilled. Samples containing anthracene (7 X 10~ M) and an appropriate concentration of the quencher were sat- 168 Solvent Temp. (SC) Ksv (M ) r ins) k~ (109M s ) ethanol 22 30 35 40 45 50 55 60 18.6 1.8 23.0 0.9 24.5 0.4 26.6 0.5 24.6 0.5 27.3 0.6 29.6 1.1 30.3 1.9 4.90 4.75 4.75 4.60 4.50 3.80 0.44 4.85 0.29 5.15 0.19 5.60 0.22 5.28 0.21 5.94 0.25 6.50 0.37 6.74 0.56 -propanol 22 30 35 40 45 50 55 60 16.1 0.8 18.5 0.9 20.5 0.8 24.7 1.3 23.0 0.9 30.5 1.3 32.4 1.2 34.1 1.2 4.40 4.25 4.25 4.25 4.00 3.67 0.26 4.35 0.30 4.82 0.28 5.81 0.42 5.40 0.32 7.18 0.45 7.86 0.44 8.53 0.47 Yolume 176, number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 11 January 1991 urated with Na2SO3 to remove the traces of 12. De- gassing of the samples was achieved by repeated freezing, pumping and thawing (five times). Sam- pies were sealed in pyrex tubes under vacuum. Flu- orescence spectra were measured using a spectro- fluorimeter (using 365/6 nm Hg lines for excitation) with a temperature-controlled sample compartment. Fluorescence lifetimes of anthracene in ethanol and propanol at different temperatures were measured using a LIF 200 Taumeter ZWG Berlin (1 ns pulse width). 4. Experimental results and discussion The fluorescence spectra of anthracene in the pres- ence of different concentrations of Nat in ethanol and n-propanol solutions were measured at different temperatures between 295 and 333 K. Stern Volmer plots were constructed from the relative integrated fluorescence intensities, and the Stern Volmer quenching coefficients Kq were obtained using the method of linear regression. The experimental re- sults are presented in table 1, where the Stern Volmer quenching coefficients K~, the quenching-rate Table 1 Measured Stern Yolmer fluorescence-quenching constants [<~~ of anthracene by I ions and fluorescence lifetimes r (k~ = coefficients kq=Kq/r, and the fluorescence lifetimes r in the absence of the quencher are given. The Arrhenius plots of In kq versus 1 / T give straight lines, thus allowing for determination of the activation en- ergy of the quenching process. The Arrhenius acti- vation energies for the fluorescence quenching of an- thracene in ethanol and n-propanol by iodide ions are given in table 2. The free enthalpy of the electron transfer between iodide ion and singlet-state excited anthracene is about 0.2 eV [14,23 25]. The quenching-rate coefficient is a function of many parameters. It includes transport properties, dielectric and relaxational properties of the solvent, dimensions of the reactants and the distance-depen- dent matrix element of the electronic interactions [14], Parameters characterizing macroscopic prop- erties of the solvents were taken from the literature [33,34]. The Debye relaxation times for ethanol and n-propanol and their temperature dependencies were investigated by Bertolini et al. [35]. Dynamical properties of these solvents were reviewed by Rips and Jortner [3]. Important intermediate parameters are the sol- vent reorganization energies [14 20]. We assume that the bispherical model [15], eq. (5), gives a rea- sonable approximation for the distance dependence of the solvent reorganizatton energy. The amplitude of the changes of this function is dependent on the radii of the reactants. The parameters, a1 and a2, were selected in such a way to obtain the reorganization energies comparable with those known from other studies [16 20]. Accordingly, partial solvation of the ions was taken into account assuming that the radii of reactants in eq. (5) are larger than the mean radii of the iodide ion (2.2 A) and the anthracene molecule (3.5 A) [36]. The increases in the radii of reactants and products were taken to be proportional to the radii of the solvent molecules. In the evaluation of the parameters, a1 and a2, we were guided by the results obtained by Johnson et al. [18] for bridged donor acceptor systems. In our cal- culations, we used 0.15 eV for hQ (mean quantum of energy in internal vibrational modes of the reac- tants). The internal reorganization energies taken into account in the present modelling were 0.0,0.15, 0.30 and 0.45 eV for S=0, 1, 2, and 3, respectively, The diffusion coefficients for aromatic molecules were evaluated using the relation given by Alwatter 169 a (A) S V(a) (eV) Ethanol n-propanol k0~ (1O9M~ s_l) E~(kJmol ) kq ~ (109M s ) E~ (kJmol ) experiment 3.8 0.4 9.2~5 3.7 0.3 19.0 5 5.6e 0 0.0060 3.8 13.4 3.7 18.8 1 0.0060 3.4 12.0 3.7 17.5 2 0.0085 3.2 11.8 3.7 17.5 3 0.015 3.4 12.3 3.7 17.6 5.6* 0 0.00107 1.4 2.7 3.7 4.3 1 0.00155 1.3 2.8 3.7 4.1 NA 2 0.0023 1.2 2.5 3.7 4.5 3 0.0035 1.1 2.1 3.7 4.8 6.0* 0 0.0080 3.1 15.2 3.7 20.6 I 0.0085 2.9 14.3 3.7 19.4 2 0.0125 2.9 14.2 3.7 19.4 3 0.0215 2.9 14.5 3.7 19.6 6.0* 0 0.00115 1.0 2.9 3.7 3.7 I 0.00175 1.0 2.7 3.7 4.2 NA 2 0.0027 1.0 2.2 3.7 4.5 3 0.0041 1.0 2.0 3.7 4.8 * denotes contact separation of reactants. (ps) 131 9.620 39.220 Tiir~ (kimol- ) [34,351 18.6 31.1 lI January 1991 Volume 176, number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS Table 2 Calculated quenching characteristics using eq. (4) for electron.transfer rate and parameters given in table 3 below. NA denotes nonadi- abatic limit et al. [371 and Wilke Chang [38], and the viscos- ities of ethanol and n-propanol. Parameters used in the present modelling are given in table 3. The external reorganization energies A (r) for large and small separations of reactants calculated from eq. (5) and parameters from table 3 are given in ta- ble 4 for ethanol and n-propanol solutions at 295 K. Parameters V(a) (eq. (6)) were fitted to repro- duce the experimental value of the quenching-rate coefficient, kq, for anthracene in n-propanol (3.7xl09M s ).Finally, these parameters, V(a), were used to calculate the quenching-rate coeffi- cients for anthracene in ethanol, as well as the ac- tivation energies of the quenching-rate coefficient for 170 Solvent a (A) A(r=a) (eV) A(r=oo) (eV) ethanol Volume 176, number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 11 January 1991 Table 4 Solvent reorganization energies (eq. (5)) S. Summary Quenching-rate coefficients of anthracene fluores- cence by iodide ions in ethanol and n-propanol were measured in the temperature range 29 5 333 K. The activation energies of the fluorescence-quenching-rate coefficients were found to be 9.2 5 kJ moLt and 18.6 5 kJ mol~ for ethanol and n-propanol, re- spectively. In the analysis of the experimental data, the diffusion of the reactants and the electron-trans- fer rates were taken into account in a self-consistent manner. For anthracene and the iodide ion, ~G is negative ( 0.2 eV) and diffusion control of the quenching reaction is moderate. This system dem- onstrates effects of the adiabaticity of the electron- transfer process using stationary quenching experiments. The parameters used in our modelling agree rea- sonably well with those derived from analysis of other systems. Remarkable agreement between experi- mental values and calculated quantities was found when relaxation properties of the solvents are taken into account. The analysis of the fluorescence quenching indicates the importance of the dielectric relaxation of the solvent for the electron-transfer process. Our conclusions are based on analysis of station- ary quenching experiments. For investigation of the influence of solvent-dielectric relaxation on electron transfer, time-resolved fluorescence measurements should provide a more direct evaluation of the effect. Acknowledgement The support of the Polish Academy of Sciences Project CPBP 01.19 is gratefully acknowledged. The authors thank Dr. J. Rodakiewicz for her help in the fluorescence-lifetime measurement and Professor J. Hicks for her editorial comments. References [Il A. Gochev, G.E. McManis and M.J. Weaver, J. Chem. Phys. 91(1989)906. 121 Y.J. Yan and S. Mukamel, J. Phys. Chem. 93(1989)6991. [31 L RipsandJ.Jortner,J. Chem. Phys. 87(1987)2090. 5.6 0.36 6.0 0.44 1.46 1.46 1.20 1.20 n-propanol 5.6 0.15 6.0 0.23 anthracene in ethanol and n-propanol. The contact separation of the reactants is smaller than a -~- a2. This is an acceptable value if we allow for the interpenetration of solvation shells. Contact separation restricts the relative translational motion of the reactants, whereas parameters a1 and a2 are related to the orientational degrees of freedom of the solvent molecules in contact with the reactants. The theoretical predictions based on eq. (4) (for the parameter p equal to lit) are given in table 2. The calculations were performed for two values of the closest-approach distance between the reactants (a=5.6 and 6.0 A). From table 2, we find that cal- culated (eq. (4)) quenching-rate coefficients and corresponding activation energies agree reasonably well with the quantities derived from experiment. However, the agreement is equally good for all val- ues of the parameter, S, when the parameter V( a) was suitably adjusted to reproduce the value of the quenching-rate coefficient in n-propanol. For comparison, table 2 shows results of the cal- culation assuming the nonadiabatic limit. As before, the parameters, V(a), were fitted to obtain the quenching-rate coefficient for anthracene in n-pro- panol. Also, other quantities were calculated using this parameter. The agreement with experimental data is poor. In particular, the calculated activation energies of the quenching-rate coefficients are much lower (negative for ethanol) than those obtained from experiment. Also, the fitted values of the ma- trix element of electronic interactions 1/( a) are rather low. This evidence supports our suggestion that sol- vent relaxation effects are important in the fluores- cence quenching of anthracene by the iodide ions in alcohols. 171 Volume 176, number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LEUERS il January 1991 [41 J.N. head.ce:title: Solvents effects on the fluorescence quenching of anthracene by iodide ions

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Faculty of Chemistry, Jagiellonian University, 3 Karasia, 30-060 Kraków, Poland

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Fluorescence quenching of anthracene by iodide ions in ethanol and propanol solutions in the temperature range 293–333 K was investigated under stationary conditions. The fluorescence quenching can be satisfactorily described using Marcus-type theory. Analysis of the experimental data indicates the importance of solvent-dielectric-relaxation properties for the fluorescence quenching.
